notesStmt.note:
Written by Shelomoh ben Alzuḳ for Yosef ben Daṿid ben Shelomoh ben Rabi Daṿid ben Gedalyah the elder: inscription (folio 434v).
Laurentius Franguellus: inscribed with his name: 'Revistu[s] p[er] me Laurentiu[s] Franguellu[s] die 26 novembris 1574' (folio 434r), see 105-110.
Luigi de Bologna: inscribed 'Revisto et corretto per me f. Luigi da Bologna del 1601' (folio 433v). A converted Jew working for the Inquisition as censor (active at the end of the sixteenth, beginning of seventeenth century), see 104, and appendix § 112-117.
Camillo Jaghel: inscribed with his name, 1613 (folio 433v), see 50-56.
Renato de Modena: inscription 'Visto p[er] me fr. Renato de Mod[ena] 1626' (f. 434); see 132-133. Erasures (e.g. ).
Bernard Mould (b. c. 1683; d. 1744), chaplain at Smyrna: inscribed with his name, Smyrna, 1724 (folio 435b); sold to Edward Harley on 28 July 1725 (see , ).
Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.

supportDesc.foliation: Hebrew foliation is the continuation of that of the first volume (folio 2 is identical with Hebrew foliation 293). Unfoliated leaf [folio 160*] after folio 160 (but it has the Hebrew foliation: 452) and one unfoliated leaf [folio 436] after folio 435.

history.provenance: Acquisition: The Harley Collection, formed by Robert Harley (b. 1661, d. 1724), 1st earl of Oxford and Mortimer, politician, and Edward Harley (b. 1689, d. 1741), 2nd earl of Oxford and Mortimer, book collector and patron of the arts. Edward Harley bequeathed the library to his widow, Henrietta Cavendish, née Holles (b. 1694, d. 1755) during her lifetime and thereafter to their daughter, Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (b. 1715, d.1785), duchess of Portland; the manuscripts were sold by the Countess and the Duchess in 1753 to the nation for £10,000 (a fraction of their contemporary value) under the Act of Parliament that also established the British Museum; the Harley manuscripts form one of the foundation collections of the British Library.
